description.text:
Come see me at the San Fransisco Maker Faire May 18-20, 2018!

I will be presenting my Mechanical Laser Show at my booth in the "dark room". I'd be happy to answer any questions and you can play with my toys.

The mechanical laser show is a device that projects a pattern by quickly moving a laser. It's
hand powered, 3d printed, open source, and free to print.

For more information and shots of it in motion, see this video:

https://youtu.be/_dtBUiaAqRE

Hackaday.io post with more info: https://hackaday.io/project/25447-mechanical-laser-show
Cam profile code: https://github.com/EvanStanford/cams

Printer:

Monoprice Mini Select

Notes:

Parts

Each part has different print settings:

  • Cams (2)
    15% fill, supports, no build plate adhesion
    I recommend increasing the "Support Distance X/Y" to 1mm or more

  • Crank gear
    15% fill, supports, large brim

  • Back Plate
    15% fill, supports, no build plate adhesion

  • Front Plate
    15% fill, no supports, no build plate adhesion

  • Crank handle
    100% fill, supports, large brim
    This piece has an arrow telling you which way to crank (clockwise). If you want it to look great, sand down with 100 grit sandpaper.

  • Fasteners (X axle + Y axle + 2*Bolt)
    50% fill, no supports, large brim
    The X and Y axles are different parts. One is right hand threaded and the other is left hand.

Parts to buy

  • Laser Pen (requires NON-rechargeable batteries)
    https://www.ebay.com/itm/361308618032 (3PCS 5MW Laser Pointer Pens preferably by batterygallery)

  • Rubberbands
    https://www.amazon.com/BAZIC-Assorted-Dimensions-Rubber-Bands/dp/B000BLJEKU
    It is important to use light rubber bands. Normal bands can provide too much force.

Optional Parts

  • Laser ring
    Holds down the power button. Alternative to tape.
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2386839
    Thanks Conmanrezac!

Version History

  • V1
    2017/06/13
    Original upload

  • V2
    2017/07/21
    All parts backwards compatible.
    Rotated threaded holes in back plate. Fastener heads should now line up better.

comments.text: I didnt know if anyone else was having problems with the back plate.  I have the monoprice mini select v2 and when it gets to a certain height (almost close to the end of the print) it just stops and with a little bit left on the progress bar.  Any suggestions?
comments.author: Walker395

comments.text: Are you using Cura? I experienced the exact issue last week with a completely different model. I printed the identical Gcode twice and it failed at the identical spot. Then I switched to Slic3r and it solved the issue. I may recommend that. Another advantage of Slic3r for the back plate is the variable Z resolution: you can have high resolution (0.1 mm) at beginning where the threads are and then fall back to lower resolution (~0.25 mm) for the rest.

comments.text:
How do u work out where the reference points are, on the shap to be projected? I would have, incorrectly, imagined them to be equidistantly spaced like on the cam but on the image of the star most the points were clumped around the tips of the star. so how do know the point ether side of the tip will correspond to a 35th of a rotation of the cam
i hope that makes sense :)
comments.author: SavageRodent

comments.text:
Hi. Great question- it makes sense.
Lets assume you are rotating the input crank at a constant speed. This means that the laser will travel between each point at a constant interval. That is- ever X milliseconds it will hit the next point. If the points were evenly spaced the laser would travel at a constant speed. This would work fine, but I spaced them differently as a small optimization.
When the points are closer together the laser moves slower. I am slowing down the laser for the sharp turns and speeding it up for the straights (similar to a race car!). I chose the exact spacing by eyeballing- there was no exact math. But you could conceptually make math for that. For example you could have a target peak acceleration and a target max speed as constraints.
comments.author: SavageRodent

comments.text:

comments.text: This is quite a brilliant idea and clearly from a mathematical mind.  But there are a lot of supports necessary and I feel that these could have been designed out.  Splitting the parts to then glue them together and avoid supports isn't really practical.  The only option is to recreate everything in another 3D CAD program, then export new stl files to press fit everything together.  This is especially true for the front plate which if split into three parts (or even just two) then re-assembled through integral pins would avoid all support.  Even the simple crank requires support, but split into two and having an integral pin, would also avoid support.  In my opinion avoiding the need for support in a 3D print design, maintains the surface finish quality, uses less filament and takes less time to print.
comments.author: paulsroom

comments.text: While designing I prioritized functionality, minimal part count, aesthetics, then printability in that order. Earlier designs had a 2 piece back plate that was cleaner to print and provided adjustability. I scrapped that in favor of a smaller part count. Since you prioritize printability higher, the ideal design would be completely different. Feel free to remix one or more parts. I will definitely print them and try them out! I designed with Sketchup and the .skp file is included (with 1000x scale).

The cams are designed for a 14.12 mm diameter laser pen.

If you decide to print this I would recommend picking up the other lasers ($10) and experiment with both.

comments.text: Wouldn't the angle technically depend on the radius of the other cam at that point as well? (if the other cam has a larger radius, the pen is pushed up more, then the angle is greater for the calculated cam). I think this would probably make the problem much more difficult though. Did you consider this? Are the implications negligible?
comments.author: Widgity

comments.text:
Yes, you are very correct. I am taking account for that issue. Let me explain:
For my first prototype I just found a list of the radii to each of the target points. Then I created cams where those radii where all X degrees apart from each other (eg if there were 36 points, each would be 10 degrees apart). This prototype had the exact issue you are describing and it was significant.
I am now accounting for this by calculating the angle that each radius protrudes from the cam at. When calculating a given point on a cam, if the opposing cam has a very large radius, that will cause the cam to increase the angle at which it puts that radius. This is done indirectly through the angle math (the second half of the math on the slide).

title: E3D v5 Mounting Plate or Base for Extruder

description.text:
Update 6/21/17: I felt this mounting plate was a quick-fix for my E3D, so I made a proper design here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2398040.

This mounting plate will allow you to install an E3Dv5 hotend to your extruder. It's a design I found on thingiverse with serious flaws that I decided to fix.

-Mounting holes now properly sized and aligned to extruder*
-Added nut carriage holes to locking clamp **

*original version had undersized holes and required additional drilling.
** original version relied on plastic to lock 3M bolts.

After testing this, I am somewhat satisfied by its performance. I noticed flexing in the original version, so will recommend against anything lower than 50% infill. Also, E3D gets very hot, so I will advice you to print this in ABS.

I will advice you against using the "simple" versions of this mounting plate. The simple versions don't lock the hot end throat and will have lateral movement along the X axis. I made the mistake of printing a simple version and was shocked by this movement.

Features:
Standard 50mm mounting holes (size from hole to hole).

Recommended settings.
ABS
.2mm layer height
50% infill

Required Hardware
2x 3M nuts
2x 3Mx25mm bolts

description.text: The factory camera mount that comes with the Syma X5C points at the ground when the quadcopter is moving forward. So I printed the SYMA X5SC horizontal camera mount by Anar and tried it out. It worked great, but only for slow flying. Flying at speed still tipped the quadcopter forward so far that I was looking at the ground most of the time. So I modified Anar's mount to angle the camera even more. Now the camera sits level with the horizon at full speed for a view that is more like FPV.

Hatchbox Alpha

title: Tom's Simple Filament Clip for (not only) Fillamentum's Spools
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This tiny thing is a must have for pro users storing their spools with material (for example in boxes with dehumidifier). I have tested many filament clips during years but every one has some flaws – from annoying everyday use to unreliable attachment. There is no reason to be frustrated by the loose or entangled material anymore.

These two clips for the most common 1.75 and 2.85mm filaments were designed from scratch to suit spools of Fillamentum brand (old black and new transparent). You can 3D print them very fast and with minimum of material. The same clips could work also with some other spool types, I have tested standard 0.75 to 1kg spools from Innofil3D, Prusa, older Ultimaker's spools etc. Just test yours.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

Clips are tested on Prusa i3 MK2 and Ultimaker 3 with 0.2mm layers. If your 3D printer is calibrated different way, just use scale compensation if you find them too loose or tight.

A simple wrist mounted fidget spinner.

It takes a standard skate bearing and 5/16" hex nuts.

The band is capable of holding a 1" by ~2mm thick fabric elastic band sewn shut or hook and loop fasteners sewn onto the ends or just a 1" hook and loop band if you don't mind the scratchiness.

Have fun, I have everything in one print and it should be capable of printing without supports but the individual parts are still included if you need a replacement part or you want to remix.

This should work with any fidget if you or your kid wants a different fidget on their wrist.

Assembly

Just glue the two halves of the watch band part together with the rod sandwiched between with some super glue and press fit the other parts by hand or with a wrench.

1) Press fit all nuts and the bearing into the spinner
2) Fit the rod into the bearing
3) Glue the two halves of the watch band together
4) Cut 1" elastic to length and sew the ends together or affix hook and loop to the ends of the elastic if you don't want a band that has to slide on and off or just go straight hook and loop, it's up to you.

description.text:
The original Ultimaker caps add useless friction to the X/Y axis bearings, so I designed these instead. Best printed in Nylon for lower friction and more durability (or check the many derivatives of this thing!)  
Update: added rounded/smoother version, slightly bigger and with optional bearing access hole (eg. to oil it if ever...)

You need 8 of them for a complete set. Some of the caps of an Ultimaker are hard to change. The easiest way was to use curved long arm pliers to hold the nuts, before I made a convenient "nut calumet" here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44118 These caps are fully parametric and were made with openscad, so they can be recycled for another use (ie. mostly keep any bearing in place on a flat surface). If you want your axis to go trough, ask me, or add a difference() with a cylinder centered at 0,0. When printing, you can keep the fill ratio quite low, because there is no load on these pieces: they are just meant to hold the axis bearing in place. Anyhow, do not expect a big saving because the piece is small and mostly made of walls (~20cm of 3mm filament). There is a small (parametric) conic pin in the middle, made to avoid too much lateral freeplay for the axis. I suspect it is useless though, and would wear out quickly anyway in case an axis really want to escape sideways ;) About the stock friction issue: http://wiki.ultimaker.com/Ultimaker_rev.3_assembly:_X-Y_axes#Step_1:_Inserting_the_ball_bearings I forgot to take pictures of used wooden caps, so I borrowed one from maxy, thanks!

comments.text: I just installed these and they work great. My wooden caps had surprisingly lot wear. Especially the front x-axis ends caps had burn marks inside(!) Bit tricky to install the rear caps, but it is possible if you remove the motors and have needle nose pliers.
comments.author: luotinen

comments.text: Great idea! I'm not sure if the friction there is really a problem with my printer, but if nothing else this will move me one step further towards making my Ultimaker look like it can upgrade itself :-)

remixed_from.title: Customizable spool holder for M3D printer

description.text:
This spool holder is intended for the M3D Pro printer, and sits on top of the unit, above the extruder, and using the printer chassis as base.

These are brackets only. Two sets are needed, one for each side, then simply add any dowel, rod or tubing of your choosing to complete this thing. Use the customizer on the right and select the tubing diameter you plan to use for the vertical risers and top axle, and the model will adapt. Be careful not to make the vertical fit too snug, or the brackets may split apart.

The vertical risers can be anything that make it tall enough to clear the printer and fit your spool size, minimum 3" recommended; I use 6" vertical risers.

The top brackets hold a horizontal axle, which can easily lift out to change filament. The horizontal top tube needs to be 8.5" in length, and can fit multiple spools.

author: santitiga

description.text:
Here's a screen printing or silk screening frame corner. It's probably already been designed, made and posted, but if so, here's another option.

This part will not make screen printing any easier but it will make screen printing cheaper. Probably the most painful part of screen printing is washing off your emulsion to reuse the frame. I know, that's my least favorite part of screen printing.

This THING is a frame corner, modeled after window screen frame corners. Yes, you will need to go to your local hardware store to get window screen frame bars. Cut the bars to size. I cut mine to 9" and 11.5" to make a frame capable of supporting 8-1.2" x 11" transparencies, plus my squeegee is 10" wide. Assembly should be straight forward - knock the corners into the frame bars to make a square frame. Then cut your silk screen fabric across and push in the cord, making sure the fabric is taught.

Printing instructions:
This part doesn't need to be pretty. However, since it will be under stress as you insert it into the frame bars, you'll want to make sure you have good layer adhesion. You might also want to increase your extrusion factor. A little extra plastic will provide a little extra friction so your frame doesn't fall apart.

Other than that, it doesn't matter what print resolution you use. These parts will get dirty and stay dirty, so nothing really matters. The point is printing these corners for $0.25 per corner (x4 corners) is better than buying these corners as a "frame kit (less the bars), for $5. You should be able to make about 3 "8-1/2x11" frames out of 2 full bars from the store. They should end up small enough as well as cheap enough to either save the artwork or just throw them away.

title: Dremel 3000 brackets for Openbuilds C-Beam 80 MM plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These brackets are made to mount a Dremel 3000 to an Openbuilds C-Beam 80 mm plate. You need a quantity of 4 x 5mm x 15 mm flat head screws and 4 x 5mm x 20 mm flat head screws, and 5 x 5mm self locking nuts plus one 40 MM long 5 MM bolt for the top bracket.

Also included are two test print STL files to determine how close your printer expands or contracts inside circles. I found that I had to make the 3/4 inch 12 TPI threaded hole about 20% larger than actual for my printer. So the bottom bracket that screws onto the nose of the Dremel is sized accordingly.

Also the 5MM holes are tight as well, but not impossible. I printed these at .3mm layer height and 50% infill.

I also calculated the center line of the Dremel to be exactly 36 MM above the plate. Your's could be different. It is possible to shim under the brackets if needed to level the Dremel further.

You can copy the files in Tinkercad and use them there from: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jQDBXzuCU6j-dremel-3000-mounts-for-open-c-beam

Change to top mount design - November 2017

Added more support for top mount as the original broke after some time.

Please note that you may need to adjust the thickness of the top (or bottom) mount where it bolts to the plate. I found that my Dremel was not vertically aligned until I removed the thickness of the rubber back coating on the Dremel where the top mount was clamping it.

I printed my mounts at 40% infill using Black Hatchbox PLA.

title: Reading Light SAAB 9-3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a courtesy (reading) light holder for a 1999-2002/3 SAAB 9-3. It is the mating part of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:221712

This fits my Saab 9-3 2003 convertible.

It is similar to SAAB p/n 2381365. I recommend making this with ABS due to the heat of the lamp that inserts into it (press fit).

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/k5NRVTRw9Xk

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Supports from (touching) base only, if that feature is on your slicer. I used Cura.

Assembly

From your kitchen or dollar store, pick up a cheap 1/4 or (better) 1/8 Teaspoon made out of shiny thin aluminum.

Cut the the handle down to about 1" length from the concave spoon end.

Bend it about 1/8" from the concave end, and inset it into the straight slot of this printed design. Press it down - on mine, the convex end barely touched the top of the light ring, when inserted.

Once the light bulb is inserted into the round retainer ring, the light from the bulb should reflect against the spoon and down through the printed part's large diameter opening hole.

I did not make a lens cover because I wanted as much light as possible, and the cover traps heat (even the factory units could melt).

title: Mini Word Clock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A 150mm square faced mini word clock.

The clock uses 72 Neopixels (8 rows x 9 pixels per row). The Neopixels are the 60 pixels per metre type. Thus, just over a metre is required.

A WIFI connection to an NTP server pool to maintains accurate time, has time zones support for areas that need Daylight Savings Time, settings for single colour colours, or more of a rainbow colour (not animated) and the colours can be set to change on the minute, hour or day.

Time can be set for auto dim and bright (day time and night time viewing).

Updating the software can be done OTA style (over the air) as long as the ESP8266 is on the same WIFI network as the Arduino IDE.

The Arduino sketch is provided (the basis of it was from an Instructable : http://www.instructables.com/id/ESP8266-NTP-TIMEZONE-CLOCK-WITH-WiFi-MANAGER/)

Note: all settings for options are in the sketch, there are no external buttons for control.

Printer:

Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

When printing the diffuser panels, I found .3 layer height and 2 layers in white works the best. Especially if you use green as a solid colour for the clock numbers.

NodeMCU's tend to come with headers already soldered in place. I simply unsoldered mine and put on female right angle headers. The reason I did this was the keep the package as low profile as I could and used female to avoid shorts between the pins.

There are only 3 wires needed to connect the Neopixels to the NodeMCU. Vcc (5V), GND and data.

The backplane has grooves the Neopixels fit in. I found some strips are slightly wider than others but they are supposed to be 10mm wide. So you might find them in a little snug...

Diffuser panels should be a press fit in. I used the blunt end of 3mm screw driver to pop them in around the edges. No glue required.

The Neopixels are wired in a continuous strip, starting from the top left (when you're looking at the Neopixel side of the backplane). I used 22 gauge solid wire and made jumpers, stranded would work just as well. My other word clock shows the wiring.

I designed sides to hold the clock face at an angle and also to hide the strip wires.

Power is coming in via the USB connection, the Neopixels 5V is picked up from the VIN pin on the NodeMCU. I've used either a RaspBerry PI adapter or an old iPhone USB charger to power the clock. Both work fine.

Although I initially designed a different mounting bracket for the NodeMCU 1.0 (ESP8266 - 12E) I ended up adding a backing plate to make it easier to mount with M3 screws. Speaking of which, M3 x 5 are what I used to assemble the sides, backplane with the WS2812B (neopixels if you like), and M3 x 6 for the ESP8266 bracket to hold it on the backplane.

In the sketch, the colour settings are here:

define colourSolid 0//

define colourRainbow 1//

uint8_t colourType = colourSolid;

define colourChangeNever 0//

define colourChangeDaily 1//

define colourChangeHourly 2//

define colourChangeMinute 3//

uint8_t colourMode = colourChangeMinute;//
//

For dimming, it's a 24 clock setting...

uint8_t dimHour = 23, dimMinute = 01;// night time in 24Hr format to dim the display
uint8_t brightHour = 8, brightMinute = 0;// daytime in 24Hr format when to brighten the display
//
The brightness of the clock is set here. I found these settings work very well..keep in mind if you change the 175 to 255 for more brightness, there probably won't be as big a change as you might expect.

uint8_t brightNight = 24; // night time brightness
uint8_t brightDay = 175;// daytime brightness
//
For updating the time, the NTP server pool would rather you don't send a request to them every minute, they suggest a much less frequent update. Plus a word clock is really a 5 minute clock so you can set how often to update the time from the server pool:

uint8_t ntpUpdateFrequency = 62;// update the time every x minutes

When the word clock powers up, it will appear as a hot spot as "MINI_WORD_CLOCK". Connect to it, run a browser, for a URL use 192.168.4.1. Select scan, pick a WIFI to connect to, enter in the password for the WIFI to connect to. The NodeMCU will reboot, connect to the Wifi, the LED on the NodeMCU will turn on to show its connected and the clock will run.

if you need to reset the connection, a jumper wire between GPIO 5 (D1) and ground, press the RESET button on the NodeMCU, wait about 5 seconds, remove the jumper, reconnect to "MINI_WORD_CLOCK" access point and select a new access point for it to connect to.

If you are worried about someone hacking into your clock via your network via OTA, uncomment this line in the sketch and put in a password. One that you'll remember..:-)

// ArduinoOTA.setPassword((const char *)"12345");

My printer has a 220mm circular print bed so I decided to see just how big a word clock I could print on it without having to piece it to together like my other larger word clock.

With this limitation in mind, the biggest face I could print was 150mm x 150mm. So I used almost every mm of it...:-) The face with the lettering prints in one go, as does all of the diffuser parts (white panels).

I did try to light the face with one metre of Neopixels (60), but I found that it gave uneven lighting in some of the words whereas the 72 pixels gives very even lighting.

description.text:
STL files along with BOM, firmware, and source files can be found here
http://www.eclips3d.com/docs.html

The Eclips3D2 is a high precision CoreXY 3D printer designed with speed, accuracy, and looks in mind! The Eclips3D2 utilizes a custom machined aluminum top plate, genuine Hiwin linear guides, an E3D V6 hotend, and perhaps the most rigid and robust corexy setup in existence. Best of all, the printer is fully open sourced, allowing you to edit and make as you see fit!

If you are interested in purchasing the machined parts or the full custom kit from my website, see here!
http://www.eclips3d.com/store/c3/Eclips3D2_Printer_Kits.html

Thanks for looking, please feel free to comment with any questions!

The Eclips3D2 is the successor to the Eclips3D (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1242295). The new printer is a full overhaul designed to be superior in every way, but still retaining the original design inspiration. Just like the Eclips3D, the Eclips3D2 is a very reliable CoreXY printer capable of producing beautiful prints time and time again!

Assembly guide is currently a WIP but it can be found here
https://www.instructables.com/id/Eclips3D2-3D-Printer-Assembly-Guide/

It should be completed in the next week or so! It includes a full step by step guide with pictures for assembling your Eclips3D2.

title: Pool Bottom Drain Cover - Low Profile

description.text: The bottom drain cover that came with my pool had a domed / high profile. This caused my robotic pool cleaner to "bottom out" when trying to cross over it - it would get stuck straddling the drain with its treads dangling off either side, unable to dislodge itself and continue cleaning. So I designed and printed this low profile replacement - just 6mm high.

Printer:

Monoprice

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.13125

Infill:

20%

Snap together - no glue required

The 5 pieces are designed to snap together. I was surprised how tightly it held without any glue. The screw holes pass through pairs of connecting tabs, providing additional strength to hold it together.

5 Pieces to fit on my small print bed

The cover is too large to fit on my 120x120 print bed, so I had to design it in pieces that snap together. I'm providing the OpenSCAD file in case anyone needs to adjust anything, but it's not well parameterized, so you'll have to reverse engineer it. Non-commercial use only, please.

comments.text: Awesome! This is perfect, because we needed a new drain cover, and my printer only does 120x120x120. Thanks for making this!
comments.author: dansl

comments.text: Thanks! I hope it works for you! You might want to double-check your screw hole locations compared to this design before printing.... I think my design is for a some-what universal (or at least common) drain cover, but you never know.
comments.author: dansl

description.text:
I took the excellent design from roklobster04 since I wanted a bolt-down jig instead of just a clamp-on. I modified a few things:

  1. Indexed the sleeve for 3/4", 1", 1.25" and 1.5" width of stock. This is on the back of the sleeve labeled 3,4,5,6 (as in quarters of an inch). All the way down is 3/4" and all the way up is 1.5". The height and placement of these is calibrated against a Kreg jig in my shop.
  2. Changed the vise plate to accommodate a washer and either a bolt head or thread-locked nut behind the aluminum clamp plate. This moves the vise plate back and forth as the screw is turned.
  3. Changed the knob to take a nut and washer that secures the knob to the shaft.
  4. Modified the jig to use one slot-inserted nut in the base instead of two (one on each end) because I had trouble getting the shaft to cinch without a lot of backlash.

The fit was very tight when printed in ABS and I modified the gaps, adding about 0.5mm for clearance on sleeve and vise mating surfaces.

The original design included all the hard work of the basic setup, and I was just able to tweak it a bit.

The original design used an aluminum plate countersunk to take a screw and fastener on the back side of the plate. I found it easier to thread the aluminum plate and use a screw from the back side, then file the screw extension on the vise plate flat.

I have ordered, but not yet tried McMaster-Carr flanged sleeve bearing number 9440T54. Will update after they arrive.

Update: The McMaster-Carr bearings arrived and fit perfectly in the jig. Attached with some CA to keep them from slipping out and did several test holes, all with great results.

Tip: Set the depth collar on the drill bit by first putting a 1/8" spacer on the bottom of the jig. Then drop the drill bit in and tighten the collar with the bit resting on the spacer.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used 4 shells for strength in the design, but this did push out the print time substantially. I've not tested to see what the minimum requirement might be but suspect it can be done in fewer.

Design files

roklobster04 was kind enough to post the solidworks design files. After converting them through Grabcad, I was able to modify the design in Fusion360. I've also posted the design files I used.

comments.text: Good question and I don't think I was clear enough in the explanation.  For each thickness setting you need to reset the collar on the drill bit.  The best way to do this is to insert the bit (after changing thickness) and set the collar to allow the bit to drop to 1/8" from the base.  This keeps the drill from drilling through the face and avoids yet another sometimes-confusing setup step using a scale like the Kreg jigs require.
comments.author: Karl_FLG

comments.text: Terrific!
comments.author: randysteck

comments.text: Great work! What drill bit do you use with this? My kreg bit doesn't want to fit...
comments.author: JewishBacon

comments.text: I use the Kreg bit in the kit I have although it's a bit short.  Plus, I ordered one specifically for this that ended up being a bit longer.  It's a standard 3/8" stepped bit with a collar and are pretty inexpensive on Amazon.  With the bushing in it may require some clearing of the plunge hole at first due to extrusion width.  But, this is easy to do with the pocket hole bit or a standard 3/8".  After drilling  half a dozen holes in the jig it frees up substantially and has been working well.

title: Epic Scale Lucius Pattern Warlord Titan

description.text:
A proxy model for Epic scale Warlord Titan (40k or armageddon etc).

super glue for assembly.
Some of the parts are right or left specific, some are ambidextrous.
if the stl has X2 in the name then print two, one for left and one for right (most leg bits, shoulder guns, arm mounts).
some parts require rotation to print with best facing upward (my program allows rotation so that's what i do).
tolerances - bring sandpaper or a small file to get some of the bits to fit.

have included a 'full model' stl just for thingiview.

the model is based in part on this model https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2328976 though i couldn't get the 75Mb stl to actually open in sketchup. the pics were useful though. based more on this model than the original Epic version but i also checked out the originals for some inspiration as well.

can look fairly 'upright' without any posing but you can position the legs to lower the stance and make it more "bam ! action!".

the model is low-poly in places but when it prints it smooths to an acceptable level at this scale. as usual paint will add a lot to the final product but there should be enough step-planes in the model to make the silhouette interesting.

i did contemplate modelling the newer 'mars pattern' version but frankly i like my titans how is like my dreadnoughts and fliers, boxy-as.

there are a couple of pre-paint pics, the body parts had a small but acceptable amount of lift which i bogged with liquid green stuff.

description.text:
This isn't really a remix of the Raspberry Pi Camera Case and Mount for Mini Kossel by @kevinlo. It's simply a printable nut for connecting the Pi camera tripod back to a tripod screw. @kevinlo's model requires a "real" nut, but I'd prefer to stick to plastic. :-)

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-17

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I'd print it at a small layer height so the threads print cleanly, but give it a relatively high amount of fill to make it strong.

Depending on your printer/slicer, you may have to tweak your horizontal size adjustments to make this nut fit correctly. A negative horizontal adjustment will make the nut looser (it will pull in all outside edges), and a positive horizontal adjustment will make the nut tighter (it will push out all outside edges).

For me, this nut prints perfectly and works very well.

title: Rubber Band Pulley Collection
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
While working on my Halbach PM generator (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2374343) i came to a point whhre i would need to eventually test it and the easiest way to do that is with the newspaper rubber bands i get from work. I know there are several pulley sets out there but i had time to kill so i designed a set that goes from 37mm to 125mm it also includes some multi-speed pulley sets. these pulles are designed to be used on a M10 bolt, because that is what i am using in the center of my PM generator, however as always i have included the Blender file so that you can mess around with it also as always the scale for print should be 10% as i design in CM and it is actually MM, you dont get as many zoom options in blender when you are doing MM and you cant get stuff just right in my experience.

there are two different sets of pulleys oines that are desinged to cap off the hub to enclose the head of the bolt in the hub and another set that are designed to ride the bolt and use the hub to lock the bolt head to the pulley, the only difference is the centers of the ones to ride the bolt have a 10MM hole in the center.

the hub and small bolt holes are for 3MM threaded objects (allthread, pan screws, bolts) on my prints and my machine the holes are small enough to not have to use nuts. miles may vary .

eventually i plan to design a derailer like a bycicle has to use the conbo gear sets to change the speed on the fly with a 9G servo,,, maybe tommorrow

UPDATE: 06/25/2017

Added Pictures of actual printed part. Been a busy week for me so i didnt get around to it until today you will notice the newspaper rubber bands fit perfectly. Will add more pictures as I print more pulleys.

Notes:

Scale to 10% pulleys are 8MM tall and the smallest is 37MM in diameter.

author: Ilslaoaycd

description.text:
Well, a little late to the party on fidget spinners, but now that I’m hooked might as well throw my take on them into the pool.

These are designed for minimalism print time & plastic use wise, all will print in about 10-15 min and are designed around 2 perimeters of a 0.4mm nozzle for a perfect thin yet solid band around the 608zz bearing. Infill can be set to whatever (I used 20%) as it will only be used a little bit in the space between the bearings.

Big Mama (50 grams) is designed for big hands, with a spin clearance radius of 43mm

Little Daddy (49 grams) is designed for smaller hands, with a spin clearance radius of 38mm

The Cheap Skate (45 grams) is my attempt to push things to the minimalistic limits, by using very little plastic and M10 steel Nuts as the outer edge weights. The CS has a tiny spin clearance radius of 32 mm for the smallest of fidgeting hands.

The Typhoon (78 grams) is simply an extension of the Cheap Skate pushing the spin clearance radius out to 47 mm and adding 3 more nuts for mega spin times.

The bearing plugs where something that I added at the last min after the photo was already taken, they are just a slug that presses into the outer bearing holes adding a tiny bit of additional weight/color.

I quickly discovered it’s pretty much all about mass and that masses distance from the center point, combined with balance and limiting friction as much as possible. However there is a bit of physical limitations mixed in, where you can only go as big as your hand allows.

Few things to think about.

While ceramic bearings are apparently the best, not all ceramic bearings are equal, so don’t get too caught up in that hype, unless you can afford to. I am using hybrid ceramic ball, metal housing bearings and its fun enough.

Remove any grease from the center bearing using a de-greaser solvent like wd-40, its debatable whether or not a little lite oil after the de-greasing is helpful, I have been using a tiny drop of PTF based tri lube, I don’t notice much of a benefit or a drawback though.

There is no reason to use the expensive bearings at the outer edges, just use cheap-o bearings everywhere other than the center bearing.

Whenever possible remove the rubber shielding on both sides of the center bearing as it only adds friction, however once exposed dust can cause friction issues too, so always use a finger guard plug after removing the bearings shields. Finger guards are good anyway as they help to avoid accidentally touching the bearing and slowing the spin.

All of the spinners in the photographs where printed on a MyOpen3D Seattle Prusa i3+ 3D printer. https://www.myopen3d.com/

Printer:

MyOpen3d Prusa i3+

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 noz, 0.3 Layer

Infill:

20%

Notes:

These are designed for PLA and to be extremely snug when pressing in the 608 bearings, if you find them too snug you might be over extruding a hair so just drop your flow factor by 1-5%, if they are too loose then something is likely wrong with your printer.

All of the spinners in the photographs where printed on a MyOpen3D Seattle Prusa i3+ 3D printer.

title: A Pool Towel Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This clip should work on most pool chairs to keep your towel from falling from the top of the chair. Just loop the towel around the top part of the chair and clip the towel onto itself. Print two clips and clip both sides.

I printed v2 in PLA and used it several times. The clips held towels tightly, but they became bendable after sitting a while in direct sunlight on hot days. I just bent them back and they were good enough to continue using. I would recommend printing in ABS or some other higher temperature plastic, if possible.

v4 is a new design based on v2, but with some reinforcement and a shorter length.

title: Generic action camera adapter for 3DR Solo gimbal

description.text:
Description

This is a customizable mounting adapter that allows you to mount a "generic" action camera roughly the same size as a GoPro in the 3DR Solo gimbal.

Overview

There are four parts that are includde in this design: the actual adapter, a retaining clip to attach the adapter to the gimbal, a counterbalance weight for the back of the gimbal, and another weight for the side.

The adapter is pretty self-explanatory. You push the camera into the front of the adapter and it "snaps in". To remove the camera, just pull.

The retaining clip is designed to be installed in place of the green clip that comes pre-installed on the gimbal. Just unscrew the single screw that holds the green clip, install the printed retaining clip in the same place, and use the screw you just removed to secure the clip.

The weights are intended to balance the camera in the gimbal. Depending on the weight of your camera, they may not be needed. However, if you do print them, be sure to use 100% infill, otherwise they will not be heavy enough to work. The back weight screws into the the gimbal with three M2x6mm screws. There are screw holes in the back of the gimbal that line up with the holes in the weight.

Customization

You'll definitely want to customize the adapter to be an exact fit for your camera, as not all of the GoPro type clones are the same size, and it won't work well if it's not a snug fit.

For example, the defaults are setup for a GitUp Git2P, which has the following dimensions:

  • Length: 59.4mm
  • Width: 41.1mm
  • Height: 19.6mm

My no-name SJ4000 clone has the following dimensions:

  • Length: 59.8mm
  • Width: 40.8mm
  • Height: 25.6mm <--- big difference in height (thickness)

Also, if you're going to use the weights, you'll need to adjust the size for your camera. The defaults are, again, for a Git2P. If you're using a different camera, you'll just need to use some trial and error to get the weight size correct.

Printing

All of the parts are designed to print without supports. The design will work in ABS or PLA. However, as PLA is a little "stiffer" than ABS, you may want to reduce the size of the bump" on the end of the retaining clips, otherwise it may be hard to insert and remove your camera.

It's also important to use a wall thickness that insures that the clips are solid and not hollow, as otherwise they will be too fragile. The clips are 3.2mm thick at the bottom so a 1.6mm wall thickness is good to use. (and works well with the commonly used 0.4mm nozzle size).

Also, given that orientation of the layers in the clips, your print is going to need good layer bonding / adhesion. Higher temperatures help with that - I printed my ABS at 240C, and PLA at 210C.

Note: Make sure to print the weights with 100% infill, otherwise they'll be too light weight to work properly.

Links

The latest version of this model is available at
https://github.com/hugheaves/SoloGimbalAdapter

tinkerCad

This 3D printed bearing is a cost saving alternative to regular bearings. This bearing is 1" ID x1.7"ODx0.5" . The STL. file is suitable for any FDM 3D printer.

As an added feature the bearings have divots cut out of the contact arms to allow for a solid/paste lubricant. The section that is removed also allows for minimal surface contact with any rod that would be used.

Best performance when used with any plastic rod for example delrin, acetal, nylon, or any polypropylene plastic.

This concept can be integrated in to 3D printed designs to limit the amount of parts as well the need for assembly after printing.

description.text:
Simple, relatively quick printing K Cup dispenser.

Tubular cylinders are .8mm thick, so it should be very quick to print with no infill movements. Plenty strong as well.

The "Main" design has everything you need to print a 3 tube dispenser which will hold 4 kcups per tube (1 hanging, 3 in reserves), including J hooks to hang from a wireshelf or other horizontal support. Alternatively, you can hang on a wall with a couple of screws/nails. If you want to hold more than 4 cups, you can print the "Extension" model to expand the tubes by 3 cups each. There are alignment pins on the bottoms of the tubes and holes on the tops, as well as on top of the hanging dispenser, and the freestanding base model. Use whatever glue is recommended for the material you're printing with (I use hotglue for most everything...lol)

description.text:
Inexpensive USB bore scopes for Android and Windows are awesome mini cameras for smart phone and PC use. (can also work with Apple iPhones using a WiFi adapter) I designed this holder to occupy a similar footprint as my Samsung S7 phone... since I often use the two together. Printed in PLA or ABS with 1.75mm support at 45 degrees it becomes a nice way to store the camera when not in use.

NOTE: these nice, but cheap ($10) bore scopes are not well made. Mine stopped working and when I opend the brightness control cover I found there is no strain relief on the cables at either end, and a wire had simply broken off its solder joint. I took a photo to document what color wire goes to which pad, cut and removed all wiring, cleaned up the solder pads, cut-stripped, and redressed the cable end, soldered it back in place and all is good now. I left a bit more lead length inside the brightness shell and will go back one day with some hot glue or similar to stabilize the wiring. In the mean time, the holder will help keep this healthy until I need it for another job.

Solidworks to STL... a fork shaped pattern, mirrored, moved, and revolved... then a cut pattern to create the gaps and a rectangular extrude to connect the two ends followed by some details to accomodate the brightness controll module and the camera head for storage. not a perfect design by any means, but functional as is.

title: Cable Management & Switch Upgrade for STARTT (TronXY-100)

description.text:
If you are like me and own a STARTT printer you know that the cable management for this printer can use some work. I spent some time trying to use as much of the supplied hardware as I could to route wires and came up with the routing shown in the images. It works very well and drastically cleans things up. To take it a step further I printed a box that hooks to the back of the printer so I could hide the excess wires running to the circuit board.

Additionally, the only way to power the printer off is to unplug from the wall or barrel connector. This is a pain and not good on the machine so I added a LED switch that I purchased from O'Reilly auto store rated at 30amps which is a little overkill, but works great.

Some of the images posted are just to show how I routed the wires and secured the wire bundles in case others are struggling to find a good solution with cable management for this printer.

I had some issues with warping on the parts, but they are functional and look way better than a rats nest of wires. May reprint in the future.
Note: All parts printed with PLA

STARTT

title: Aurora 3D Printed Drone 180 Racer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
180 FPV drone racing platform. Depending on the infill settings and printing materials used it will withstand crashes.

Recommended hardware:

  • 4 x 4.5 inch props
  • motors between 2450kv to 2650kv and a 12N14P frame work
  • small 36mm x 36mm flight controller (tested with Dodo)
  • 4 in one 36mm x 36mm electronic speed controller (tested with Favourite 20Ax4)
  • small 25mw VTX with fixed antena mount (tested with Foxeer TM25)
  • small FPV camera (tested with Foxeer Arrow V1)
  • VTX antena
  • 30mm round aluminum standoffs used to secure the POD (5mm diameter)
  • steel screws to hold motors (6mm recommended thread length)
  • 4s 1300mah lipo

Printing recommendations:

  • POD should be printed with flexible filament, 70% infill and 1mm wall thickness.
  • Landing skids should be printed with flexible filament, 35% infill and 1mm wall thickness.
  • Bottom plate must be printed with a rigid filament such as ABS or PLA with the flat part towards the building plate. 35% to 70% infill (anything higher will be to heavy), 1mm to 2mm wall thickness and 3mm to 4mm bottom and top layers.

Setting low infill values will make the frame as light as it carbon fiber counterparts or maybe lighter. Unfortunately this will sacrifice strength. On the other hand setting higher values will make it stronger but heavier. With todays common 3d printed material such as ABS and PLA this frame will never be stronger than CNC carbon fiber parts. If you test the frame with better materials let me know how it goes.

Dimensions:

  • All the files are in mm

They're more comfortable than laces and the magnets I've used are stronger than the commercially available magnetic laces and won't come undone unless you want them to. You'll need 8 magnets that are rectangular and sized 20x10x5mm

I made this extension because I ran into an issue with the parts from bit brain for inverted dual Z (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2334406) {My remix here -> https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2383861). The wheels that run the x gantry up and down will run into the top of the bottom brackets. So this extension serves the get the nozzle lower down so the wheels don't run into the brackets.

Its 7mm thick.

You will need longer screws for the heat sink BUT YOU ALREADY HAVE THEM.

  • The tevo instructions have you use long M3 screws for the motherboard fan but they can be swapped with the 4 shorter M3's that are already in the top of your heat sink. Problem solved.

description.text:
An Infiniti license plate frame which doesn't block the state name on your license plate, because if it blocks the state name, the guy who inspects your car might be a stickler and take it off.

The frame I bought off Amazon blocked the state name and the guy who inspected my car was a stickler and took it off, which is why I made this one.

description.text:
Compatible with HP DPS-750RB A Server powersupply.
It will probably work on most HP powersupplies that have built in fans.

Useful for charging lipo batteries or anywhere you need up to 750 watts of 12v power!

To assemble, short the first and forth pads from the left with a switch. The two large pads will then provide ~12.3 volts.

Use a zip tie to secure the large wires to the metal frame to prevent the solder joints from breaking if they get pulled.

Parts

  • Rocker Switch I purchased this one from amazon

  • Led
    Any 5mm led will work. I used a white led and a 680ohm resistor. Any resistor between 220 and 800ohms should work. If you want to be precise, calculate the required resistor here

The screw is just a standard hard drive screw. I used a washer since the screw was a little bit too long.

Versions

2.0 - Redesigned to allow for air flow
1.0 - Initial design (deleted because would overheat)

Canada 150 Birthday Fidget Spinner

It’s Canada’s birthday, so let’s celebrate with a sweet spinner. This is my little tribute as a new Canadian.

To make the spinner you will need the following:

  • 6x Canadian quarters ($1.50)
  • 1x 608 bearing

I printed ABS 0.3mm layers at 70% infill with 3 solid layers top and bottom. The maple leaf is to the print bed.

I applied a small amount of Elmer’s glue stick to the face of 3 coins and placed them on the print bed to dry.

At the 15th layer I dropped in a quarter in each pocket.

This was repeated at the start of the 18th layer I dropped in the remaining 3 quarters glue side up. You may need to check what your last layer is before it closes in.

The bearing is press fit in. I used a touch of glue to secure the caps. There are probably better ones out there.

Enjoy.

I purchased a few THSL-300-8D Z-Axis threaded rod upgrades for a bunch of Prusa i3 DIY clones I built. The trapezoidal TR8 screw nuts @ 22mm wide, did not fit the Prusa Z-Axis parts as they were smaller then the ones Prusa uses.

I hunted for the proper sized TR8 sized nuts and nothing, nada, bub-kiss... Not wanting to reprint the ABS parts, I just decided to build a simple adapter. Taking a nod from Tom Sanladerer's "Z-Axis nut Holdah" for 5mm threaded rods on his Dolly i3 Clone, I remixed his nut holder to fit the TR8 trapezoidal nut, included 2xM3 nut recesses on the bottom and 2xM3 bolt/cap recesses on the top.

Basically, push the nuts into the underside, screw the adapter into the Z-Axis threaded rod slots and use a pair of M3x6mm or 7mm cap bolts to secure the whole thing into place. If you can't find the right size M3 bolts, pretty much any near size and some M3 washers will due just fine.

One small trick to get the nuts in easier, as the recesses are intentionally a tight fit, place an M3 bolt with a washer through the top side of the adapter, screw the nut on the shaft, guide the nut into the recess and tighten the bolt, the nut will work it's way into the recess real easy as you tighten the bolt.

print_settings.Notes:: I used Simplify3D to generate the supports; the settings I used were default except I set the Maximum Overhang Angle to 89 degrees to prevent unnecessary support material being generated. If you need support for the top of the circular holes in the sides then reduce the angle from 89 degrees until you get the amount of support you need. If you need support for the slots in the sides then reduce the Support Pillar Resolution from 4mm to 1mm. Also if printing using a layer height of 0.1mm then increase Upper & Lower Vertical Separation from 1 to 2.

title: Cube in a cube in a cube

description.text: For those of you who liked my cube in a cube here's something a bit more challenging. This is a solid cube loosely imprisoned inside a cut-away cube which in turn is loosely imprisoned inside another cut-away cube.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm or 0.2mm

Notes:

I used Simplify3D to generate the supports; the settings I used were default except I set the Maximum Overhang Angle to 89 degrees to prevent unnecessary support material being generated. If you need support for the top of the circular holes in the sides then reduce the angle from 89 degrees until you get the amount of support you need. If you need support for the slots in the sides then reduce the Support Pillar Resolution from 4mm to 1mm. Also if printing using a layer height of 0.1mm then increase Upper & Lower Vertical Separation from 1 to 2.

I used a sharp craft knife and a thin-bladed screwdriver to remove the support material.
Tip 1: cut two squares of thin plywood the same size as the cube and hold the cube firmly between them when removing the support material.
Tip 2 : remove all the support material attached to the innermost cube before removing the material attached to the outermost cube.

remixed_from.author: Puppetx
remixed_from.title: Atom Armor for RotorX Atom RX122 with supports

description.text:
This is Rotorx Atom v3 (4mm) armor boot with an integrated soft mount. Use soft material when printing like TPU. I cut supports with wire nippers, but a hobby knife should also do the trick.

Two versions, I used the v3.3 version with extra dampening rings, these appear to have worked well with m2x8mm screws.

Original armor by spencergs, updated with supports by myself, then extended for 4mm frame by btimby. I used softmount by dayve.

Merged/adjusted objects in freecad.

.1: fix orientation
Test1: the stretched armor is not wide enough for my frame (3.4mm according to cad), I removed this model
.2: further extend the z axis on the boot to fit my frame ~4.1mm and move mount back to better align holes.
.3: added additional rings for added dampening and to make sure 8mm screws don't short.

comments.text: Hey, great idea combining these things! The bumpers in PLA would split and come off after a couple flights. TPU would not stay put without glue (and would eventually come loose after a few flights). With the physical connection via motor screws+soft mounting, this is a winner!
comments.author: btimby

description.text:
Dieses "Thing" dient dazu, einen Beamer auf einen Kamera Stativ anzubringen.
Weitere Benötigte Teile:
1x 1/4 Zoll Mutter
3x Beilagscheibe mit 5-6 mm Innendurchmesser
(zu finden bei z.B. www.zollshop.de) Montage:
  • Teile drucken
  • Teile putzen
  • In die Sechskanttasche eine 1/4" Mutter stecken und mit einem Lötkolben oder heißen Schraubenzieher die Kante der Tasche leicht verformen, um die Mutter gegen herausfallen zu sichern.
  • Die drei Arme und eine dünne Beilagscheibe auf die Zapfen stecken. (Notfalls reichen auch zurecht geschnittene Alufolien-Stücke)
  • Mit einem Breiten Lötkolben oder einem heißen großen Schlitzschraubenzieher die überstehenden Enden der Zapfen etwas platt drücken.
    • Hinweise:
    -Achten Sie bei der Montage darauf, den Beamer-Schwerpunkt möglichst über der 1/4" Mutter zu positionieren.
    -Verwenden Sie ein Stativ und Stativkopf mit ausreichender Nutzlast P.S.: noch konnte ich meine Konstruktion noch nicht selbst testen, daher würde ich mich über ein Feedback von euch freuen.

XY for 12mm y and 10mm X and 9mm GT2.

Printed and fit tested for assembly. Not yet run

title: Tamron Adaptall 2 Base/Bottom/Rear Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement end cap to protect the rear element of Tamron Adaptall 2 lenses without an adaptor attached. The original rear caps are notoriously fragile, a situation that has worsened due to age and the plastics becoming brittle. Those that are available cost a ridiculous amount, so I decided to design my own.

Although the overall height is less than the original, internally there is more height clearance. I've tried the design on a number of lenses including the SP 2x Teleconvertor which has a protruding rear element.

I printed in PLA with no supports. Seems to be strong enough.

title: Faceted Heart
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Is there somebody you have a secret crush on? Let them know this Valentines with our 'Faceted Heart'. This simple but stunning heart has been specially designed to be 3d printed in gorgeous PLA. Print out one for them (in their favourite colour) and one for you. Leave their heart somewhere they will find it with a note saying 'I'll wear mine if you wear yours.' Then wear your heart and see what happens. We've designed two wearable hearts - one is a pendant and the other is a tie clip. Go on. You never know what may happen! ;)

These should print well with 2 perimeters and 5% infill. Tie Clip
There are two versions of the tie clip so both men and women can wear it. One is a right-sliding clip for shirts that button to the left. This is labelled as 'male' because most men's shirts button to the left. The other is a left-sliding clip for shirts that button to the right. This is labelled as 'female' because most women's shirts button to the right. The Heart Pendant simply needs a chain or ribbon which can be threaded through the hole at the top.

comments.text: so simple and beautiful :)

description.text: Armattan Japalura is the fanciest micro frame around, and the second design in Armattan’s selection that features aluminum protection. Inspired by many of the same principals as the Chameleon, the Japalura is a lighter, more compact package that still supports many of today’s FPV standards. This “4 inch” frame can handle full-sized miniquad guts, houses your standard HS1177 camera, and shields everything but the lipo battery with two 4mm thick 6061 aluminum ribs.

Part List

Frame: Armattan Japalura 4″ – $77.5
ESC: TATTU 30A BLHeli_S ESC $67.96
Motors: 4 x Brotherhobby Tornado T1 1407 3600KV $63.96
Battery: Tattu 1300mAh 4S 75C Lipo Battery $28.99 Tattu 850mAh 4S 75C Lipo Battery $18.86
Propellers: DAL 4045 Regular $2.19
FPV Camera: RunCam Swift 2 (2.5mm lens) – Orange $39.99
FPV Transmitter: TBS Unify Pro 5G8 HV (SMA) $49.95
Antenna: Lumenier Pagoda 2 5.8GHz Antenna (RHCP) $11.99
Receiver: FrSky X4R-SB – 3/16 Channel Receiver with SBUS and CPPM without pins $24.99
Misc Parts: Anti-Vibration Flight Controller Standoff $3.39

Other than what is listed below, here are a few bench necessities for any build:

Zip ties
Blue loctite
Heatshrink of various sizes
Paracord 550 (optional)
A nylon nut set with 2mm and 1mm spacers

Mounting the Flight Controller

It’s best to start by fitting the stack. Sometimes this can be the most time consuming part of the build depending on your stack space and standoff selection. It’s definitely good to have a wide variety of standoffs on hand because the included standoffs rarely ever work. Here I used 7mm anti-vibration standoffs. While most flight controllers work just fine, soft mounted or not, these are less prone to break and could potentially improve flight performance. That being said, they can be troublesome to fit as the female end is more shallow than a typical standoff. I ended up sending a 5mm screw with a 1mm spacer through the bottom plate into the anti-vibration standoffs. Without the spacer the threading is too long.

Motors

Next you’ll want to mount the motors. Normally I attach them using two screws at first in the event that I need to remove them for whatever reason. Just don’t forget to finish them up with loctite before the maiden. Once the motors are in place and the flight controller is mounted you’ll want to cut the wires to length. I used 2″ lengths Paracord 550 to protect the wires, but that’s entirely optional.

You’ll want to cut each motor wire to length individually to reach their respective ESC pads. While KISS doesn’t support motor rotation changes via software, you can solder jumper pads to change the rotation as necessary. To cut each wire you need to lay it down flat against the arm, run it up to the standoff, follow the edge of the board and divert straight up into the groove of the ESC pad. It’s important that the wires remain under the flight control board otherwise they’ll get in the way of the canopy mounts.

You’ll also want to solder the XT30 connector to the Lipo input pads of the flight controller. I like a short lead here, so 2-3cm should be sufficient.

Receiver

Since KISS doesn’t allow you to test your motor rotation without a bound transmitter, you’ll want to wire up your receiver first. This is fairly straightforward, so just refer to the photos to learn the wire positions. To prepare the FC pads, add a little flux and create a nice shiny pillow of solder. The key is to leave none of the copper pad showing. This is where a quality iron is important. If the solder makes a pointy bit as you pull away you either aren’t operating at a high enough temperature (750 to 800 degrees) or your iron tip lacks sufficient flux.

Now you need to bind your RX and test the motor rotation. First download the latest KISS “CC” FC Firmware and install KissFC to Google Chrome. To update the firmware open KissFC, plug the USB cable into your flight controller, hold the boot button and plug the other end into your computer. While continuing to hold the button choose the firmware you downloaded and flash it. If you let go too early the process will fail.

After the firmware has been updated, attach a lipo, connect to the board and click “Data Output” to test the motor rotation. I normally rub each motor to feel the rotation direction. For any motor that spins the incorrect direction solder the corresponding JP1 jumper for that motor. Refer to the KISS CompactCTRL “CC” Manual for details.

Once you’ve completed these steps you can mount your RX and antennas. What I did was use a couple layers of double sided tape to prevent any potential shorts against the flight controller. Using wide shrink tube would be a better solution, but I had none wide enough for this RX. The antennas are incredibly long, so I rotated the U.fl connectors 180 degrees to send the antennas forward. I wrapped them around the standoffs across to the other side, and out behind the front arms. If you do it just right you’ll manage 2in of zip tie for the tips of both antennas.

Canopy and FPV

Now you can assemble the canopy and wire the camera and VTX. Be sure to mount the antenna holder flat side out so the wings of the pigtail catch the lip. This prevents the pigtail from rotating as you attach your antenna. Since we’ll eventually be using TBS Smartaudio, you can solder the audio wire of the VTX to the TX pad of the FC. Now depending on which version of the TBS Unify you’re using (HV or 5V) you’ll either want to solder the power leads to the lipo input pads or the RX 5v/GND pads. Once you’ve done this you can solder the Runcam wires to the VTX wires to complete the wiring. Just be sure to leave enough slack to remove the canopy.

Finishing up!

Now you can attach the canopy being careful not to pinch any motor wires. I found that the pigtail can assert just enough pressure to hold the VTX to the top of the RX, so I didn’t use any tape to hold it down. It seems to fit just right behind the camera, so I don’t believe it’ll be moving around in there. Be sure to loctite your motors and you should be ready to maiden!

author: Renman_inJapan

description.text: a Simple End stop Bracket for the OneUp and TwoUp 3D printers Z-Axis. Slides easily down the 8mm rods with a singe M3 screw to clamp. Designed to work for the Mechanical End stop v1.2 but may work for others.

Printed 1:1 scale using 100% infill. Infill may be reduced to 80% but wouldn't recommend going any lower. To attach: For 0 End stop:
Simply remove the top plate, slide the X-Axis Gantry off. Slide the end stop bracket down the drive side with the two end stop holes on towards the top. slide the Gantry back down and replace the top plate. Next attach the end stop, set the Z-axis and tighten down. For Max End Stop:
For 0 End stop:
Simply remove the top plate, Slide the end stop bracket down the drive side with the end stop mounting holes towards the bottom. Replace the top plate. Next attach the end stop, set the bracket to the upper limit and tighten the clamp.

author: Sanek1985

title: FT-817 crank knob with custom Oogoo sleeve

description.text: I didn't really like the rather hard rubber surface of the original knob and wanted a crank anyway, so I made a crank knob and a fitting Oogoo mold to make a softer rubber sleeve for it. I also included an STL of the rubber sleeve if you want to try printing it with flexible filament. The diameter of the sleeve is 1 mm smaller than the knob to create a tight fit. Update: This thing is featured in the August edition of the DARC (German Amateur Radio Club) magazine CQDL: http://www.darc.de/cq-dl/

Printable without support, axle hole down for the knob - the bridge there was no problem in my print.
You may have to sand down part 2 of the mold a bit so that it fits snuggly into part 1. Fill with Oogoo to your taste and let it set. I thinned the Oogoo with a little bit of cleaning solvent to make it softer. To fully fill the mold and avoid air bubbles, for me it was better to fill the outer mold first and then drive the inner part in in as the walls of the Oogoo part itself will be very thin. When it is dry, you can easily remove the inner part of the mold again and get a nice rubber sleeve for your custom made knob.
On the knob, thread the screw hole with an M3 screw and insert the original screw from the old knob. Sand the axle hole to make it fit the axle and attach the knob with the screw. Put on the Oogoo sleeve and gd DX!

comments.text: Nice  :-)    .  73 from Poland  from Jerry  SP3SWJ   :-)

comments.text: 1/2 lb (229 grams) that is heavy, You need to print these with no infill and thin to make it work. Also as the other guy stated these are huge and will act as sails in the air along with how they are mounted on there stop your lift.
comments.author: kendallb

comments.text:
On take-off, you're also dealing with surface adhesion due to the large surface area of the floats. Aircraft floats are usualy boat-hull shaped, or ribbed, to break the grip of the water. This is especialy true for helicopter floats, as they lift straight up. Floats of this size, you could be looking at 1 to 2 pounds of additional 'weight' as you lift off, & then you get into the wind resistence of a round ended object...
PET water bottles might be a very light-weight option as well, & come in dozens of different shapes & sizes.
comments.author: sandman67

comments.text: Just a thought...   but why not use balloons for the floats.  Just modify the bracket a little bit.  That would cut a lot of weight.
comments.author: Talonzz

comments.text: Yes correct I have to find a lite version for the floats.
comments.author: Talonzz

title: Yamaha Monitor Magnetically attached Bass Grill

description.text:
Element grill for Yamaha speakers to protect it from fingers and pointy animal limbs.
Glued on 8mm x 1mm neodymium magnets to make removal easy, as element have hex bolts on them.
Print needs support because of special Z wave design, but hope is this makes it cooler and stronger when finished.

My model is HS7, but the file should probably be able to scale to the other models..

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Had to use concentric support and 2mm outer layers to make thinnest parts solid. If not there is a lot of vibrations and the precision goes down.
Also stopped at Z height to change filament for the logo as I have a UM2 and not UM3.
The logo is designed higher than the rest to make this possible.
